page.title: 06The Whittlebury Skeleton
page.content: On 15th May 1984 the occupants of number 13 High Street were mending their drive. After digging down just over a metre they discovered a bone. Further careful excavation revealed an almost entire human skeleton. The police and an archaeologist were informed. It was thought the remains were possibly Roman because of the proximity of Towcester, an ancient Roman camp, but as the skeleton was lying W to E the idea was rejected. Another possibility was linked to a missing tax collector, a man greatly disliked locally who disappeared in the 1890s. The skeleton was given burial by the vicar on 26th May and now lies under the yew trees in the churchyard of St Mary's, Whittlebury.
